Expectation1: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation1: An external auditor has just requested specific financial statements for an immediate review.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I was hunched over my desk, double-checking the quarterly reports when the email from the external auditor popped up. They needed the financial statements—immediately. My heart raced. Accuracy was everything in my job as an accountant, and I couldn’t afford a single error, especially not with an audit looming. But today was also election day, and I’d promised myself I’d vote before heading back to the office. 

At the polling station, I joined the line, clutching my ID and thinking through the numbers I’d left unfinished. Suddenly, an official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line!” My last name was Baker. The new line was longer, but the official insisted. I hesitated, glancing at my watch. The auditor’s request echoed in my mind—I needed every spare minute to get those statements right. But as a voter, I was expected to follow the officials’ instructions, no questions asked. 

I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. Should I obey the official and risk losing precious time, or stay put and risk being reprimanded for not following the rules? My mind spun, caught between duty and responsibility, unable to move forward.
